title: COVID-19 and Chronic Liver Disease
author: Sonya Collins

content: More than 4 in 5 people who have symptoms of COVID-19 , the illness caused by the coronavirus , get only mildly sick. But if you have ongoing health issues, including liver disease , the virus may be more likely to leave you seriously ill.

content_blocks.text: More than 4 in 5 people who have symptoms of COVID-19 , the illness caused by the coronavirus , get only mildly sick. But if you have ongoing health issues, including liver disease , the virus may be more likely to leave you seriously ill.

sections.heading: Link Between COVID-19 and Your Liver
content: According to the CDC, some patients hospitalized for COVID-19 have had increased levels of liver enzymes — such as alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). This means a person’s liver is at least temporarily damaged during their illness.

In addition, studies indicate that people with preexisting liver disease (chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, or related complications) who were diagnosed with COVID-19 are at higher risk of death than people without preexisting liver disease.

content_blocks.text: According to the CDC, some patients hospitalized for COVID-19 have had increased levels of liver enzymes — such as alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). This means a person’s liver is at least temporarily damaged during their illness.

In addition, studies indicate that people with preexisting liver disease (chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, or related complications) who were diagnosed with COVID-19 are at higher risk of death than people without preexisting liver disease.

sections.heading: Serious COVID-19
content: Most people with COVID-19 symptoms get better on their own. And a sizeable number of people who catch COVID-19 show no signs. But a small portion of people do fall severely ill or die. They may get severe lung problems , such as pneumonia and ARDS ( acute respiratory distress syndrome ). Pneumonia can swell your airways and fill your lungs with fluid. That can lead to ARDS, which makes it hard or impossible for you to breathe . Some people may need a ventilator .
Things that may raise your chances of severe COVID-19 include if you:
bullets: Have a weakened immune system because of  HIV, autoimmune hepatitis , and organ transplant
Have a lung disease like asthma or COPD
Have mood disorders like depression or bipolar disorder

associated_bullets: Have a weakened immune system because of  HIV, autoimmune hepatitis , and organ transplant

Have mood disorders like depression or bipolar disorder

sections.heading: How to Protect Yourself
content: You can take these steps to help you avoid COVID-19.
First, get vaccinated. If you have a higher risk for illness, you might:
If you think you might have symptoms of COVID-19, like a fever or dry cough , call your doctor.
bullets: Avoid close contact with others, especially those who may be sick.
Clean and disinfect surfaces you touch often, such as phones, TV remotes, countertops, faucets, and light switches.

sources: CDC: "What to Know About Liver Disease and COVID-19," “Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) People Who Need Extra Precautions – What You Can Do,” “Mortality and Morbidity Weekly Report, March 31, 2020,” “Chronic Liver Disease and Cirrhosis,” “About Cloth Face Coverings.” “Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, July 17, 2020.”
The Lancet : “Liver injury in COVID-19: management and challenges.”
American Liver Foundation: “Important Information: The Coronavirus and Liver Disease.”
meta_description: People with underlying chronic liver disease, or even risks for liver disease, should be treated similarly to other high-risk groups since an overreaction from the immune system can lead to disease progression. Learn more about the link between COVID-19 and your liver, here.
